Abstract

The width Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T of the deconfinement transition region is shown to influence strongly the flow structure in the (Landauâ€“) hydrodynamical expansion of a quarkâ€“gluon plasma. For a sharp first order transition (Î”â¢T=0Î”ğ‘‡0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0) the mixed phase is rather long-lived, with a lifetime that has a maximum when the initial energy density is at the phase boundary between mixed and pure quarkâ€“gluon matter. For increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, however, the lifetime decreases rapidly. Hadronic matter, however, remains long-lived as a consequence of the rapid change in the degrees of freedom in the transition region and the corresponding â€œsofteningâ€ of the equation of state.

In the ideal fluid approximation, the (equilibrium) equation of state is the only input to the hydrodynamical equations of motion (1) that relates to properties of the matter under consideration and is thus able to influence the dynamical evolution of the system. The final results are uniquely determined once a particular initial condition and a decoupling (â€œfreezeâ€“outâ€) hypersurface are specified.

In ultrarelativistic heavyâ€“ion collisions (sâˆ¼200similar-toğ‘ 200italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:200\sqrt{s}\sim 200 AGeV), the central region (in the center-of-momentum frame) is essentially free of (net) charges, due to the insufficient amount of baryon stopping [5], and the charge conservation equations in (1) do not have to be solved explicitly to describe the fluid evolution in this particular region of spaceâ€“time. Moreover, the equation of state depends only on a single independent thermodynamical variable, for instance the temperature Tğ‘‡italic-TT. From the pressure as a function of Tğ‘‡italic-TT, pâ¢(T)ğ‘ğ‘‡italic-p OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)p(T), one derives the entropy density sâ‰¡dâ¢p/dâ¢Tğ‘ dğ‘dğ‘‡italic-s RELOP:equivalent-to d italic-p MULOP:divide d italic-Ts\equiv{\rm d}p/{\rm d}T, and the energy density Ïµâ‰¡Tâ¢s-pitalic-Ïµğ‘‡ğ‘ ğ‘italic-epsilon RELOP:equivalent-to italic-T italic-s ADDOP:minus italic-p\epsilon\equiv Ts-p.

For this particular case, lattice QCD calculations [6] provide fundamental information on the equation of state of strongly interacting matter. These calculations [7] show a rapid increase of the entropy density as a function of temperature, sâ¢(T)ğ‘ ğ‘‡italic-s OPEN:( italic-T CLOSE:)s(T), in a narrow temperature interval Î”â¢Tâˆ¼10similar-toÎ”ğ‘‡10Delta italic-T RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\Delta T\sim 10 MeV around a temperature Tcâ‰ƒ150similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘150italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:150T_{c}\simeq 150 MeV, indicating the presence of a transition from hadronic degrees of freedom at low temperatures to quark and gluon degrees of freedom at high temperatures. For a first order phase transition, the increase in sğ‘ italic-ss is actually a discontinuity, and Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T is zero, while for a second or higher order transition the change of the entropy density is continuous, and Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T is finite. Thusfar, however, lattice calculations have not converged on the order of the QCD phase transition [8, 9, 10], and we only know that Î”â¢Tâ‰¤0.1â¢TcÎ”ğ‘‡0.1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T\leq 0.1\,T_{c}.

In this paper we discuss the sensitivity of the structure of hydrodynamic flow to this uncertainty in the equation of state. To this end we treat the width Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T of the transition region as a free parameter and assume the following functional form for the entropy density [11],

The first study of the sensitivity of hydrodynamic flow on Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T was done in [11]. It was found that for Î”â¢T<Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T<\Delta T^{*}, where Î”â¢T*â‰ƒ0.07â¢Tcsimilar-to-or-equalsÎ”superscriptğ‘‡0.07subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.07 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T^{*}\simeq 0.07\,T_{c}, matter is thermodynamically anomalous in the phase transition region and, consequently, that rarefaction shock waves occur in the oneâ€“dimensional expansion [13, 14]. On the other hand, for Î”â¢Tâ‰¥Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}, matter is thermodynamically normal everywhere and simple rarefaction waves form the hydrodynamically stable solution. The main result of Ref.Â [11], however, was that, for the particular initial conditions chosen in that work, those structural differences had little effect on the final flow pattern. This led the authors of [11] to the conclusion that observables, such as the distribution of outgoing particles, would hardly be affected by the uncertainty in Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T.

Renewed interest in the sensitivity of hydrodynamic flow on the equation of state has arisen as a consequence of the work of Refs.Â [14, 15, 16]. It was demonstrated that a phase transition leads to a so-called [15] â€œsoftest pointâ€ in the equation of state, defined by a minimum in the ratio p/Ïµğ‘italic-Ïµitalic-p MULOP:divide italic-epsilonp/\epsilon. For the equation of state (3) with Î”â¢T=0Î”ğ‘‡0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, this point occurs at the phase boundary between mixed and pure quarkâ€“gluon matter (see also Section 2). It was argued [15] that at this point the comparatively small pressure prevents a fast expansion and cooling of the system. This leads to a maximum in the lifetime of mixed phase matter as a function of the initial energy density. On this basis it was suggested [15] that the resulting enhanced emission of electromagnetic probes from this long-lived mixed phase could serve as a signature for the creation of the quarkâ€“gluon plasma in ultrarelativistic heavyâ€“ion collisions.

In Ref.Â [16], the suppressed tendency for expansion at the softest point was shown to cause a minimum in the excitation function of the directed transverse collective flow in semi-peripheral collisions. It was proposed that this minimum would also be a unique signature for the phase transition. Another important observable sensitive to the lifetime of the plasma is pion interferometry [17]. In the standard â€œslowly burning logâ€ scenario inspired by the small deflagration velocities associated with sharp transitions [18] one expects a dramatic difference between â€œoutâ€â€“ and â€œsideâ€â€“correlations, which could serve as a signal of the phase transition.

In the present work, we investigate the hydrodynamic flow pattern for oneâ€“dimensional expansion in greater detail than in [11]. In particular, we focus on the question of the lifetime of different parts of the system as a function of the initial energy density Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} and the width Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T of the transition region. While oneâ€“dimensional hydrodynamics is not realistic for a detailed comparison with heavyâ€“ion data, its simplicity allows us to study the influence of the equation of state on the hydrodynamic flow without additional effects originating from more complicated geometries.

We confirm the observation made in [11] that, for initial energy densities well above or below the softest point of the equation of state, the temperature profiles in the thermodynamically normal case (Î”â¢Tâ‰¥Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}) look indeed similar to those in the thermodynamically anomalous case (Î”â¢T<Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T<\Delta T^{*}). However, we demonstrate that the temperature profiles are quite sensitive to a variation of Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T for Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} near the softest point of the equation of state. In particular, the lifetime of matter with temperatures near Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} decreases rapidly for increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T. On the other hand, the lifetime of matter with temperatures well below Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} remains large and may even grow for increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T. This is due to the â€œsofteningâ€ of the equation of state by the change of degrees of freedom across the transition region. Thus, the detectability of the quarkâ€“gluon plasma via enhanced emission of electromagnetic probes may depend sensitively on Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, while other observables such as flow and correlation functions are expected to remain fairly insensitive to that uncertainty.

This paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we review properties of the equation of state (3) in greater detail and establish the connection to thermodynamically normal or anomalous behaviour. Section 3 presents the expansion solutions as functions of Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} and Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T. In Section 4 we discuss the lifetimes of parts of the system having different temperatures. Section 5 concludes this work with a summary of our results.

Matter is called thermodynamically normal if Î£Î£Sigma\Sigma is positive and thermodynamically anomalous if it is negative. It was shown in [11, 13, 14] that in the first case the hydrodynamically stable solution for the oneâ€“dimensional expansion of semi-infinite matter is a simple rarefaction wave, while in the latter case it is a rarefaction shock wave. Depending on the value of Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, the equation of state (3) features thermodynamically normal as well as thermodynamically anomalous regions, as discussed below. The hydrodynamical solution for the oneâ€“dimensional expansion of semi-infinite matter may thus consist of a sequence of simple waves and shocks. For the oneâ€“dimensional expansion of finite matter, the expansion solution is that for semi-infinite matter as long as the rarefaction waves have not reached the center of symmetry of the system (usually taken to be the center of the coordinate system, x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0). Afterwards, the solution no longer consists only of simple waves and shocks but is more complicated (see also next section). An analytic solution is so far only known for thermodynamically normal matter with a constant velocity of sound [20].

3 Oneâ€“dimensional expansion solutions

In this section the oneâ€“dimensional hydrodynamic expansion of a finite slab of matter with (homogeneously distributed) initial energy density Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} is investigated with emphasis on the dependence of the flow structure on Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} and Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T. To solve the hydrodynamic equations (1) in (1+1)â€“dimensions we employ the relativistic Hartenâ€“Laxâ€“van Leerâ€“Einfeldt (HLLE) algorithm presented in [14, 22] with a grid spacing of Î”â¢x=0.025â¢RÎ”ğ‘¥0.025ğ‘…Delta italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.025 italic-R\Delta x=0.025\,R (2â¢R2ğ‘…NUMBER:2 italic-R2\,R being the initial size of the slab) and a time step width of Î”â¢t=0.99â¢Î”â¢xÎ”ğ‘¡0.99Î”ğ‘¥Delta italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.99 Delta italic-x\Delta t=0.99\,\Delta x. This algorithm was shown [14] to accurately reproduce hydrodynamic flow profiles for analytically solvable test problems where the equation of state has thermodynamically normal as well as anomalous regions. In particular, for the choice Î”â¢x=0.025â¢RÎ”ğ‘¥0.025ğ‘…Delta italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.025 italic-R\Delta x=0.025\,R, the algorithm accurately reproduced the expansion solution for a finite system of size 2â¢R2ğ‘…NUMBER:2 italic-R2\,R consisting of thermodynamically normal matter with a constant velocity of sound. (This solution was first provided by Landau in purely analytical form [20], but can also be easily constructed semi-analytically via the method of characteristics [23].)

Note that the temperature and CM energy density profiles show a minimum at x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 for late times tğ‘¡italic-tt. As was explained in [14], this is essentially a relativistic effect. At finite xğ‘¥italic-xx, matter is moving, while due to symmetry it is at rest at x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. Moving matter, however, experiences relativistic time dilation and is thus less diluted and still hotter at a given time in the CM frame than matter at rest. Of course, the degree of dilation a fluid element experiences is determined by its velocity. This velocity is, in turn, determined by the â€œstiffnessâ€ of the equation of state, i.e., the ratio of pressure to energy density, since that ratio influences the acceleration of fluid elements. Thus, for the typical energy densities occurring in Fig.Â 3, matter velocities are smaller for larger values of Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, since the equation of state is softer, cf.Â Fig.Â 2 (b). This explains why the minimum at x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 (or the time dilation effect, respectively) is less pronounced (and occurs at later times) in Figs.Â 3 (c,f) than for instance in Figs.Â 3 (a,d).

Then, a rarefaction shock wave provides further dilution. This can be most clearly seen in the CM energy density profiles, Fig.Â 4 (e). The reason why the temperature profiles, Fig.Â 4 (b), do not clearly exhibit this behaviour is that Tğ‘‡italic-TT is proportional to a fractional power of Ïµitalic-Ïµitalic-epsilon\epsilon, so that the range of high energy densities is not well resolved when plotted as a function of temperature. A clear indication for this behaviour, however, can be found comparing the spaceâ€“time diagram Fig.Â 4 (g), where the (T=0.9â¢Tc)ğ‘‡0.9subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.9\,T_{c})â€“ and (T=Tc)ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=T_{c})â€“isotherms coincide, since both temperatures occur at the position of the shock, with Fig.Â 4 (h), where they are well separated due to the simple rarefaction wave preceding the shock. Note that this has a drastic influence on the lifetime of matter with T=Tcğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T RELOP:equals italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=T_{c}. Such matter is thermodynamically normal for finite Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, as discussed in the context of Fig.Â 2 (d), and consequently rapidly diluted by the simple rarefaction wave. The lifetime drops by more than a factor of 2 as compared to Fig.Â 4 (g). On the other hand, the lifetime of matter with T=0.9â¢Tcğ‘‡0.9subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT=0.9\,T_{c} remains comparable to that in the case Î”â¢T=0Î”ğ‘‡0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0, since this temperature occurs on the rarefaction shock front, cf.Â Fig.Â 4 (b), as was also the case in Fig.Â 4 (a). This case is of interest since for initial energy densities of this order of magnitude a rather peculiar phenomenon occurs in the expansion for an equation of state with Î”â¢T=0Î”ğ‘‡0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0. One observes in Figs.Â 6 (a,d) that the rarefaction shock wave is now driven outwards by the pre-acceleration from the simple rarefaction wave, as was already discussed above. Matter behind the shock experiences cooling typical for the Landau expansion with a sufficiently stiff equation of state, i.e., slower matter near the center x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 cools more rapidly than faster matter at larger x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. The occurrence of the second shock could have been expected, since matter changes from thermodynamically anomalous in the mixed phase to thermodynamically normal in the hadron phase. To our knowledge there is now, however, no general mathematical theorem rigorously proving the existence of this second shock, as was the case in the expansion of semi-infinite matter studied in [14]. The shock has an interesting further consequence: just as the first shock expells hadronic matter outwards, the second accelerates matter inwards. Therefore, there is an accumulation of matter in the center which is consequently reheated instead of cooled. This reheating of the center can be clearly seen in Fig.Â 6 (g), where the triangle-shaped isotherm at small xğ‘¥italic-xx and tâˆ¼70â¢Rsimilar-toğ‘¡70ğ‘…italic-t RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:70 italic-Rt\sim 70\,R is a re-occurrence of the (T=0.9â¢Tc)ğ‘‡0.9subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.9\,T_{c})â€“isotherm caused by reheating. In addition, also the (T=0.7â¢Tc)ğ‘‡0.7subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘OPEN:( italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.7 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(T=0.7\,T_{c})â€“isotherm shows that the central region remains hot over a much longer period of time than for the expansion of matter without a phase transition.

4 Lifetime of parts of the system having different temperatures

In this section we discuss the lifetimes of parts of the system having different temperatures. The â€œlifetimeâ€ is defined as the time it takes the system to cool below a certain temperature T*superscriptğ‘‡italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endT^{*} at x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. More precisely, the â€œlifetimeâ€ is the intercept of the isotherm tâ¢(x;T*)ğ‘¡ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘‡italic-t OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:; italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)t(x;T^{*}) in the (t-x)ğ‘¡ğ‘¥OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:minus italic-x CLOSE:)(t-x)â€“plane with the tğ‘¡italic-ttâ€“axis, i.e., tlâ¢iâ¢fâ¢eâ‰¡tâ¢(0;T*)subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘–ğ‘“ğ‘’ğ‘¡0superscriptğ‘‡italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-i italic-f italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equivalent-to italic-t OPEN:( NUMBER:0 PUNCT:; italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)t_{life}\equiv t(0;T^{*}). We choose the point x=0ğ‘¥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0 to measure this time, since the motion of fluid cells at finite xğ‘¥italic-xx causes a time dilation which leads to a slower cooling when measured in the global CM frame of the system. In case there is more than one intercept, for instance when there is reheating of the center, Fig.Â 6 (g), we choose the first.

We investigate the lifetime in two different geometries. In subsection 4.1 we study longitudinal expansion for fixed initial â€œradiusâ€ Rğ‘…italic-RR of the system. In subsection 4.2 we investigate a more realistic geometry where the initial longitudinal size Rğ‘…italic-RR takes into account the Lorentz contraction of the colliding nuclei. Thus, Rğ‘…italic-RR varies with beam energy, and hence with the initial energy density Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0}.

In general, the more rapid cooling of matter with higher temperatures as well as the delayed cooling of matter with smaller temperatures is well explained by the increasing â€œstiffnessâ€ of the equation of state at higher energy densities and its â€œsofteningâ€ at smaller energy densities for increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, cf.Â Fig.Â 2 (b).

An important conclusion to be drawn from Figs.Â 8 and 9 is that for increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T the maximum in the lifetime of matter with temperature around Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} vanishes and that, for Î”â¢T=0.1â¢TcÎ”ğ‘‡0.1subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T=0.1\,T_{c}, there is no longer any irregularity that can be traced to the rapid variation of thermodynamical quantities in the phase transition region. In fact, in that case the shapes of the lifetime curves resemble those for the expansion of an ideal gas, cf.Â Figs.Â 8 (c) and (d). However, the existence of a transition from hadronic to quark and gluon degrees of freedom, the softening of the equation of state induced by that transition, and the resulting delayed expansion causes the lifetimes to be larger by an overall factor âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10, cf.Â also Fig.Â 9. We will discuss possible implications for proposed quarkâ€“gluonâ€“plasma signatures in the next section.

On the other hand, if one accounts for the Lorentz contraction of the initial size of the system, then such maxima in the lifetime persist even for finite Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T. This is in contrast to the case without a phase transition, where the lifetimes rather exhibit minima for the corresponding values of Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} (Figs.Â 10, 12 (d)). The lifetimes are also much longer (a factor of âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10) in case a rapid change in the degrees of freedom occurs. Experimental implications will be discussed in the next section.

5 Summary and Conclusions

In this work we have studied the oneâ€“dimensional hydrodynamic expansion of a finite system with an equation of state featuring a transition between (baryon-free) hadronic matter (with 3 massless degrees of freedom) and a quarkâ€“gluon plasma (with 37 massless degrees of freedom). The systemâ€™s evolution was studied as a function of its initial energy density Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} (which was assumed to be homogeneous) and the width Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T of the phase transition region in the equation of state. For Î”â¢T<Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:less-than Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T<\Delta T^{*}, where Î”â¢T*â‰ƒ0.07676â¢Tcsimilar-to-or-equalsÎ”superscriptğ‘‡0.07676subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.07676 italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta T^{*}\simeq 0.07676\,T_{c}, the equation of state has regions where matter becomes thermodynamically anomalous. Thus, rarefaction shock waves appear in the oneâ€“dimensional expansion, in contrast to the case Î”â¢Tâ‰¥Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}, where matter is thermodynamically normal for all energy densities and (overlapping) simple waves form the hydrodynamically stable expansion solution.

Temperature profiles are not very sensitive to Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T for initial energy densities well above and below the softest point of the equation of state, in agreement with the results of [11]. Variations of Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T have, however, an appreciable influence on the temperature profiles for Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} near the softest point. In particular, rarefaction shocks are much weaker for finite Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T than in the case Î”â¢T=0Î”ğ‘‡0Delta italic-T RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\Delta T=0 and transform into â€œbumpsâ€ resembling smeared shocks in the thermodynamically normal case Î”â¢Tâ‰¥Î”â¢T*Î”ğ‘‡Î”superscriptğ‘‡Delta italic-T RELOP:greater-than-or-equals Delta italic-T POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta T\geq\Delta T^{*}. The shock strength is much smaller because, as shown via eq.Â (10), the region where matter is thermodynamically anomalous shrinks abruptly when Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T becomes finite. The â€œbumpâ€ structures in the thermodynamically normal case appear due to the variation of the velocity of sound in the transition region. In general, the equation of state at high energy densities becomes increasingly stiffer for increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, which leads to more rapid expansion and cooling of the hot parts of the system. On the other hand, it becomes softer at smaller energy densities and thus the cooler parts of the system expand less rapidly and keep their temperature longer.

The above results were obtained assuming oneâ€“dimensional geometry and neglecting the finite (net) baryon density in the stopping regime. Nevertheless, we consider possible experimental consequences that may apply also in more realistic situations. The most important consequence from the experimental point of view is that the lifetimes of matter with temperatures near Tcsubscriptğ‘‡ğ‘italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:endT_{c} decrease rapidly with increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, if Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} is in the vicinity of the softest point of the equation of state. This will have an effect on the electromagnetic signature proposed in [15]. For instance, the rate (per unit volume) of direct thermal photons with energy Eğ¸italic-EE emitted from quarkâ€“gluon matter (at rest) is given by [25]

This makes a direct thermal electromagnetic signal of the quarkâ€“gluon plasma much more difficult to disentangle from background sources. On the other hand, after taking into account the expected Lorentz contraction of the initial size of the system, all lifetimes assume a maximum as a function of Ïµ0subscriptitalic-Ïµ0italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\epsilon_{0} at the softest point of the equation of state, cf.Â Figs.Â 11, 12, independent of Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T. The detection of this feature is, however, complicated by the broadening of this maximum with increasing Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T.

The generic feature that remains independent of Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T is that the lifetimes of matter of any temperature are larger by a factor of âˆ¼10similar-toabsent10RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:10\sim 10 as compared to the ideal gas case. In this respect, the interferometric signal of such long lifetimes associated with a phase transition to the quarkâ€“gluon plasma [17] appears to be less sensitive to Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T than hard electromagnetic probes.

Finally we comment on the signature proposed in Ref.Â [16], where it was shown that the excitation function of the directed transverse flow has a minimum generated by the softest point of the equation of state, or in other words, the minimum in the function p/Ïµğ‘italic-Ïµitalic-p MULOP:divide italic-epsilonp/\epsilon. Such a minimum still exists even for finite Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T, cf.Â Fig.Â 2 (b). However, the intrinsic dynamical mechanism for the decrease of the transverse directed flow was the inertness of the mixed phase that prevented it to expand and deflect spectator matter. This inertness is weakened at finite Î”â¢TÎ”ğ‘‡Delta italic-T\Delta T and hot matter in the phase transition region expands and cools much more rapidly than in the case of a strong first order phase transition, although still much slower than if there were no transition at all, cf.Â Figs.Â 8 (c) and (d). Further and more detailed, threeâ€“dimensional studies [26] are required before a definite conclusion of the effect on the transverse directed flow can be drawn.
